Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intrathecal Morphine Doses in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized into three groups

Participants.evidence: Conducted at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, this retrospective, single-center study involved 75 patients undergoing primary TKA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized into three groups: a control group receiving continuous adductor canal block (CCACB) and two experimental groups receiving single-dose adductor canal block (SSACB) with either 100 mcg or 150 mcg of ITM.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare two ITM doses to identify the optimal dose for analgesic efficacy and minimal side effects.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was oral morphine equivalents (OME) consumption within 24 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using a random numbers generator

Number_Randomised.evidence: this retrospective, single-center study involved 75 patients

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU), both ITM groups experienced significantly lower OME consumption and pain scores compared to the control group (p<0.001). Cumulative OME at 24 hours was significantly lower in ITM groups (p=0.004).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events, including respiratory depression, were reported.
